padding: 0px; margin: 0px;"><legend style="font-weight: 600; margin-bottom: 8px;">Which nerve innervates the rectus abdominis muscle?</legend><ul style="list-style: none; padding: 0px;"><li><div class="quiz-option" data-testid="quiz-option" data-qa="quiz-option" role="group" aria-label="Quiz option: A. Intercostal nerves (T7–T11) and subcostal nerve (T12)" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_002-0-0-de60a9e9-63e5-4a39-9d6a-17a2fc964587" aria-label="Option A: Intercostal nerves (T7–T11) and subcostal nerve (T12)" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="0" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_002-0-de60a9e9-63e5-4a39-9d6a-17a2fc964587" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_002-0-0-de60a9e9-63e5-4a39-9d6a-17a2fc964587" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">A.</label> Intercostal nerves (T7–T11) and subcostal nerve (T12)</div></li><li><div class="quiz-option" data-testid="quiz-option" data-qa="quiz-option" role="group" aria-label="Quiz option: B. Iliohypogastric nerve" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_002-1-0-de60a9e9-63e5-4a39-9d6a-17a2fc964587" aria-label="Option B: Iliohypogastric nerve" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_002-0-de60a9e9-63e5-4a39-9d6a-17a2fc964587" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_002-1-0-de60a9e9-63e5-4a39-9d6a-17a2fc964587" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">B.</label> Iliohypogastric nerve</div></li><li><div class="quiz-option" data-testid="quiz-option" data-qa="quiz-option" role="group" aria-label="Quiz option: C. Femoral nerve" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_002-2-0-de60a9e9-63e5-4a39-9d6a-17a2fc964587" aria-label="Option C: Femoral nerve" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_002-0-de60a9e9-63e5-4a39-9d6a-17a2fc964587" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_002-2-0-de60a9e9-63e5-4a39-9d6a-17a2fc964587" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">C.</label> Femoral nerve</div></li><li><div class="quiz-option" data-testid="quiz-option" data-qa="quiz-option" role="group" aria-label="Quiz option: D. Lumbar plexus" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_002-3-0-de60a9e9-63e5-4a39-9d6a-17a2fc964587" aria-label="Option D: Lumbar plexus" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_002-0-de60a9e9-63e5-4a39-9d6a-17a2fc964587" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_002-3-0-de60a9e9-63e5-4a39-9d6a-17a2fc964587" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">D.</label> Lumbar plexus</div></li></ul></fieldset><div class="quiz-explanation">Quick Tip: The rectus abdominis is innervated by lower thoracic spinal nerves.</div><div style="color: rgb(37, 99, 235); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 15px;">More Info: Specifically, the intercostal nerves from T7 to T11 and the subcostal nerve (T12) innervate the rectus abdominis, allowing voluntary motor control during trunk flexion and compression of abdominal contents.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: This is relevant when assessing abdominal wall weakness or post-surgical nerve impairment.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;">Source: Netter's Atlas of Human Anatomy</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;"><span>Tags: rectus abdominis, innervation, spinal nerves </span><span>Keywords: thoracic nerves, intercostal, core control</span></div><div class="quiz-actions" role="group" aria-label="Quiz navigation actions"><button disabled="" aria-label="Previous question" role="button" aria-disabled="true">Previous</button><button disabled="" aria-label="Next question" role="button" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="0" data-testid="quiz-next-btn" style="visibility: visible;">Next</button><button aria-label="Finish quiz early" role="button" disabled="" aria-disabled="true">Finish</button></div></div></main></main><footer class="app-footer"><input class="question-search-bar" placeholder="Search questions..." aria-label="Search questions" type="text"></footer></div>

It’s key in abdominal wall stability and core strength.Clinical Application: Massage that encourages deep abdominal relaxation can improve coordination of the transverse abdominis for core support.What is the origin of the rectus abdominis muscle?Your answer: No answerCorrect answer: Pubic crest and pubic symphysisExplanation: The rectus abdominis originates from the pubic crest and symphysis.More Info: The rectus abdominis muscle originates from the pubic crest and pubic symphysis and inserts on the xiphoid process and costal cartilages of ribs 5–7. It plays a vital role in trunk flexion and intra-abdominal pressure regulation.Clinical Application: Understanding this helps massage therapists treat lower abdominal strain or address postural imbalance in anterior pelvic tilt.Answered: 1 / 2(Some questions were skipped or left unanswered)Close

Vagus nerve" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_008-3-0-7045f2c8-c273-413e-a953-7aec9a8ea986" aria-label="Option D: Vagus nerve" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_008-0-7045f2c8-c273-413e-a953-7aec9a8ea986" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_008-3-0-7045f2c8-c273-413e-a953-7aec9a8ea986" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">D.</label> Vagus nerve</div></li></ul></fieldset><div class="quiz-explanation">Quick Tip: It is innervated by both thoracic and upper lumbar nerves.</div><div style="color: rgb(37, 99, 235); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 15px;">More Info: The transverse abdominis receives motor innervation from thoracoabdominal nerves (T7–T11), subcostal nerve (T12), and iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves (L1), providing deep abdominal stability.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: Core training or massage for back pain often focuses on this muscle’s role in spinal support.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;">Source: Principles of Anatomy and Physiology – Tortora</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;"><span>Tags: transverse abdominis, L1, T7–T12 </span><span>Keywords: nerve supply, abdominal wall, core</span></div><div class="quiz-actions" role="group" aria-label="Quiz navigation actions"><button disabled="" aria-label="Previous question" role="button" aria-disabled="true">Previous</button><button disabled="" aria-label="Next question" role="button" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="0" data-testid="quiz-next-btn" style="visibility: visible;">Next</button><button aria-label="Finish quiz early" role="button" disabled="" aria-disabled="true">Finish</button></div></div></main></main><footer class="app-footer"><input class="question-search-bar" placeholder="Search questions..." aria-label="Search questions" type="text"></footer></div>

It helps with trunk rotation, lateral flexion, and abdominal compression.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: Massage work on this area can ease tension from repetitive twisting or poor posture.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;">Source: Muscles: Testing and Function – Kendall</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;"><span>Tags: external oblique, origin, ribs </span><span>Keywords: abdominal muscle, torso, core</span></div><div class="quiz-actions" role="group" aria-label="Quiz navigation actions"><button disabled="" aria-label="Previous question" role="button" aria-disabled="true">Previous</button><button disabled="" aria-label="Next question" role="button" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="0" data-testid="quiz-next-btn" style="visibility: visible;">Next</button><button aria-label="Finish quiz early" role="button" disabled="" aria-disabled="true">Finish</button></div></div></main></main><footer class="app-footer"><input class="question-search-bar" placeholder="Search questions..." aria-label="Search questions" type="text"></footer></div>

These nerves allow trunk motion and abdominal wall compression.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: A massage therapist targeting abdominal breathing or tension may stimulate these nerves for relaxation.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;">Source: Clinical Anatomy – Snell</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;"><span>Tags: thoracoabdominal, abdominal wall, external oblique </span><span>Keywords: nerve supply, trunk movement, T12</span></div><div class="quiz-actions" role="group" aria-label="Quiz navigation actions"><button disabled="" aria-label="Previous question" role="button" aria-disabled="true">Previous</button><button disabled="" aria-label="Next question" role="button" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="0" data-testid="quiz-next-btn" style="visibility: visible;">Next</button><button aria-label="Finish quiz early" role="button" disabled="" aria-disabled="true">Finish</button></div></div></main></main><footer class="app-footer"><input class="question-search-bar" placeholder="Search questions..." aria-label="Search questions" type="text"></footer></div>

Transverse abdominis" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_010-3-0-0dc35987-6c2e-4749-ba38-653bc3941ff3" aria-label="Option D: Transverse abdominis" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_010-0-0dc35987-6c2e-4749-ba38-653bc3941ff3" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_010-3-0-0dc35987-6c2e-4749-ba38-653bc3941ff3" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">D.</label> Transverse abdominis</div></li></ul></fieldset><div class="quiz-explanation">Quick Tip: All these muscles contract to assist in expelling air from the lungs.</div><div style="color: rgb(37, 99, 235); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 15px;">More Info: During forced expiration, abdominal muscles contract to compress the abdominal cavity, elevate the diaphragm, and push air out. This includes the rectus, obliques, and transverse muscles.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: Massage can facilitate more effective breathing by improving abdominal compliance and reducing tension in these muscles.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;">Source: Clinical Anatomy – Snell</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;"><span>Tags: expiration, abdominals, forced breathing </span><span>Keywords: respiratory function, abdominal compression, core</span></div><div class="quiz-actions" role="group" aria-label="Quiz navigation actions"><button disabled="" aria-label="Previous question" role="button" aria-disabled="true">Previous</button><button disabled="" aria-label="Next question" role="button" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="0" data-testid="quiz-next-btn" style="visibility: visible;">Next</button><button aria-label="Finish quiz early" role="button" disabled="" aria-disabled="true">Finish</button></div></div></main></main><footer class="app-footer"><input class="question-search-bar" placeholder="Search questions..." aria-label="Search questions" type="text"></footer></div>

It helps with trunk rotation, lateral flexion, and abdominal compression.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: Massage work on this area can ease tension from repetitive twisting or poor posture.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;">Source: Muscles: Testing and Function – Kendall</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;"><span>Tags: external oblique, origin, ribs </span><span>Keywords: abdominal muscle, torso, core</span></div><div class="quiz-actions" role="group" aria-label="Quiz navigation actions"><button disabled="" aria-label="Previous question" role="button" aria-disabled="true">Previous</button><button disabled="" aria-label="Next question" role="button" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="0" data-testid="quiz-next-btn" style="visibility: visible;">Next</button><button aria-label="Finish quiz early" role="button" disabled="" aria-disabled="true">Finish</button></div></div></main></main><footer class="app-footer"><input class="question-search-bar" placeholder="Search questions..." aria-label="Search questions" type="text"></footer></div>

It helps with trunk rotation, lateral flexion, and abdominal compression.Clinical Application: Massage work on this area can ease tension from repetitive twisting or poor posture.Answered: 1 / 2(Some questions were skipped or left unanswered)Close

Thoracoabdominal nerves (T7–T11) and subcostal nerve (T12)" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-0-0-281f17e1-07f5-4a2e-830d-428be38c07c7" aria-label="Option A: Thoracoabdominal nerves (T7–T11) and subcostal nerve (T12)" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="0" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-0-281f17e1-07f5-4a2e-830d-428be38c07c7" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-0-0-281f17e1-07f5-4a2e-830d-428be38c07c7" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">A.</label> Thoracoabdominal nerves (T7–T11) and subcostal nerve (T12)</div></li><li><div class="quiz-option" data-testid="quiz-option" data-qa="quiz-option" role="group" aria-label="Quiz option: B. Phrenic nerve" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-1-0-281f17e1-07f5-4a2e-830d-428be38c07c7" aria-label="Option B: Phrenic nerve" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-0-281f17e1-07f5-4a2e-830d-428be38c07c7" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-1-0-281f17e1-07f5-4a2e-830d-428be38c07c7" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">B.</label> Phrenic nerve</div></li><li><div class="quiz-option" data-testid="quiz-option" data-qa="quiz-option" role="group" aria-label="Quiz option: C. Ilioinguinal nerve" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-2-0-281f17e1-07f5-4a2e-830d-428be38c07c7" aria-label="Option C: Ilioinguinal nerve" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-0-281f17e1-07f5-4a2e-830d-428be38c07c7" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-2-0-281f17e1-07f5-4a2e-830d-428be38c07c7" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">C.</label> Ilioinguinal nerve</div></li><li><div class="quiz-option" data-testid="quiz-option" data-qa="quiz-option" role="group" aria-label="Quiz option: D. Femoral nerve" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-3-0-281f17e1-07f5-4a2e-830d-428be38c07c7" aria-label="Option D: Femoral nerve" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-0-281f17e1-07f5-4a2e-830d-428be38c07c7" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-3-0-281f17e1-07f5-4a2e-830d-428be38c07c7" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">D.</label> Femoral nerve</div></li></ul></fieldset><div class="quiz-explanation">Quick Tip: The external oblique is innervated by lower thoracic spinal nerves.</div><div style="color: rgb(37, 99, 235); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 15px;">More Info: Thoracoabdominal nerves (continuations of intercostals) from T7–T11 and the subcostal nerve (T12) supply the external oblique. These nerves allow trunk motion and abdominal wall compression.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: A massage therapist targeting abdominal breathing or tension may stimulate these nerves for relaxation.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;">Source: Clinical Anatomy – Snell</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;"><span>Tags: thoracoabdominal, abdominal wall, external oblique </span><span>Keywords: nerve supply, trunk movement, T12</span></div><div class="quiz-actions" role="group" aria-label="Quiz navigation actions"><button disabled="" aria-label="Previous question" role="button" aria-disabled="true">Previous</button><button disabled="" aria-label="Next question" role="button" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="0" data-testid="quiz-next-btn" style="visibility: visible;">Next</button><button aria-label="Finish quiz early" role="button" disabled="" aria-disabled="true">Finish</button></div></div></main></main><footer class="app-footer"><input class="question-search-bar" placeholder="Search questions..." aria-label="Search questions" type="text"></footer></div>

These nerves allow trunk motion and abdominal wall compression.Clinical Application: A massage therapist targeting abdominal breathing or tension may stimulate these nerves for relaxation.Answered: 1 / 1Close

These nerves allow trunk motion and abdominal wall compression.Clinical Application: A massage therapist targeting abdominal breathing or tension may stimulate these nerves for relaxation.What nerve supplies the internal oblique muscle?Your answer: No answerCorrect answer: Lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and L1Explanation: It is innervated by thoracoabdominal nerves and the L1 nerve.More Info: The internal oblique receives motor supply from thoracoabdominal nerves (T7–T11), subcostal (T12), and contributions from iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves (L1), coordinating trunk flexion and abdominal compression.Clinical Application: Knowledge of this innervation helps when working with patients recovering from abdominal surgery or sports injuries.Answered: 1 / 2(Some questions were skipped or left unanswered)Close

Phrenic nerve" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-1-0-4747ecf2-1816-40e6-8457-effbd0e93cce" aria-label="Option B: Phrenic nerve" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-0-4747ecf2-1816-40e6-8457-effbd0e93cce" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-1-0-4747ecf2-1816-40e6-8457-effbd0e93cce" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">B.</label> Phrenic nerve</div></li><li><div class="quiz-option" data-testid="quiz-option" data-qa="quiz-option" role="group" aria-label="Quiz option: C. Ilioinguinal nerve" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-2-0-4747ecf2-1816-40e6-8457-effbd0e93cce" aria-label="Option C: Ilioinguinal nerve" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-0-4747ecf2-1816-40e6-8457-effbd0e93cce" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-2-0-4747ecf2-1816-40e6-8457-effbd0e93cce" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">C.</label> Ilioinguinal nerve</div></li><li><div class="quiz-option" data-testid="quiz-option" data-qa="quiz-option" role="group" aria-label="Quiz option: D. Femoral nerve" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-3-0-4747ecf2-1816-40e6-8457-effbd0e93cce" aria-label="Option D: Femoral nerve" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-0-4747ecf2-1816-40e6-8457-effbd0e93cce" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_004-3-0-4747ecf2-1816-40e6-8457-effbd0e93cce" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">D.</label> Femoral nerve</div></li></ul></fieldset><div class="quiz-explanation">Quick Tip: The external oblique is innervated by lower thoracic spinal nerves.</div><div style="color: rgb(37, 99, 235); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 15px;">More Info: Thoracoabdominal nerves (continuations of intercostals) from T7–T11 and the subcostal nerve (T12) supply the external oblique. These nerves allow trunk motion and abdominal wall compression.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: A massage therapist targeting abdominal breathing or tension may stimulate these nerves for relaxation.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;">Source: Clinical Anatomy – Snell</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;"><span>Tags: thoracoabdominal, abdominal wall, external oblique </span><span>Keywords: nerve supply, trunk movement, T12</span></div><div class="quiz-actions" role="group" aria-label="Quiz navigation actions"><button disabled="" aria-label="Previous question" role="button" aria-disabled="true">Previous</button><button disabled="" aria-label="Next question" role="button" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="0" data-testid="quiz-next-btn" style="visibility: visible;">Next</button><button aria-label="Finish quiz early" role="button" disabled="" aria-disabled="true">Finish</button></div></div></main></main><footer class="app-footer"><input class="question-search-bar" placeholder="Search questions..." aria-label="Search questions" type="text"></footer></div>

margin-top: 8px; font-size: 15px;">More Info: The transverse abdominis receives motor innervation from thoracoabdominal nerves (T7–T11), subcostal nerve (T12), and iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves (L1), providing deep abdominal stability.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: Core training or massage for back pain often focuses on this muscle’s role in spinal support.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; Internal and external obliques" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_010-2-0-cc499a29-2445-49c9-8b2d-c64dcf18ba44" aria-label="Option C: Internal and external obliques" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_010-0-cc499a29-2445-49c9-8b2d-c64dcf18ba44" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_010-2-0-cc499a29-2445-49c9-8b2d-c64dcf18ba44" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">C.</label> Internal and external obliques</div></li><li><div class="quiz-option" data-testid="quiz-option" data-qa="quiz-option" role="group" aria-label="Quiz option: D. Transverse abdominis" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_010-3-0-cc499a29-2445-49c9-8b2d-c64dcf18ba44" aria-label="Option D: Transverse abdominis" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_010-0-cc499a29-2445-49c9-8b2d-c64dcf18ba44" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_010-3-0-cc499a29-2445-49c9-8b2d-c64dcf18ba44" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">D.</label> Transverse abdominis</div></li></ul></fieldset><div class="quiz-explanation">Quick Tip: All these muscles contract to assist in expelling air from the lungs.</div><div style="color: rgb(37, 99, 235); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 15px;">More Info: During forced expiration, abdominal muscles contract to compress the abdominal cavity, elevate the diaphragm, and push air out. This includes the rectus, obliques, and transverse muscles.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: Massage can facilitate more effective breathing by improving abdominal compliance and reducing tension in these muscles.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;">Source: Clinical Anatomy – Snell</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;"><span>Tags: expiration, abdominals, forced breathing </span><span>Keywords: respiratory function, abdominal compression, core</span></div><div class="quiz-actions" role="group" aria-label="Quiz navigation actions"><button disabled="" aria-label="Previous question" role="button" aria-disabled="true">Previous</button><button disabled="" aria-label="Next question" role="button" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="0" data-testid="quiz-next-btn" style="visibility: visible;">Next</button><button aria-label="Finish quiz early" role="button" disabled="" aria-disabled="true">Finish</button></div></div></main></main><footer class="app-footer"><input class="question-search-bar" placeholder="Search questions..." aria-label="Search questions" type="text"></footer></div>

It’s key in abdominal wall stability and core strength.Clinical Application: Massage that encourages deep abdominal relaxation can improve coordination of the transverse abdominis for core support.Where does the internal oblique muscle originate?Your answer: No answerCorrect answer: Thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, and inguinal ligamentExplanation: The internal oblique arises from fascia and bony landmarks of the lower torso.More Info: This muscle originates from the thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, and lateral half of the inguinal ligament. It contributes to trunk rotation and compression of abdominal contents.Clinical Application: In cases of lateral strain or scoliosis, internal oblique involvement may be targeted in therapy.Answered: 1 / 2(Some questions were skipped or left unanswered)Close

It plays a vital role in trunk flexion and intra-abdominal pressure regulation.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: Understanding this helps massage therapists treat lower abdominal strain or address postural imbalance in anterior pelvic tilt.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;">Source: Trail Guide to the Body – Biel</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;"><span>Tags: rectus abdominis, origin, core muscles </span><span>Keywords: pubic crest, abdominal muscle, origin</span></div><div class="quiz-actions" role="group" aria-label="Quiz navigation actions"><button disabled="" aria-label="Previous question" role="button" aria-disabled="true">Previous</button><button disabled="" aria-label="Next question" role="button" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="0" data-testid="quiz-next-btn" style="visibility: visible;">Next</button><button aria-label="Finish quiz early" role="button" disabled="" aria-disabled="true">Finish</button></div></div></main></main><footer class="app-footer"><input class="question-search-bar" placeholder="Search questions..." aria-label="Search questions" type="text"></footer></div>

[E2E DEBUG] quizResultsText after early finish: Start New QuizResultsOther1 / 1Accuracy by TopicOther: 1 / 1 correct (100%)Quiz ResultsYour score: 1 / 2Average Time per Question: 0 secLongest Correct Streak: 1Accuracy by Topic:Other: 1 / 1 (100%)Try Another QuizWhat nerve supplies the internal oblique muscle?Your answer: Lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and L1Correct answer: Lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and L1Explanation: It is innervated by thoracoabdominal nerves and the L1 nerve.More Info: The internal oblique receives motor supply from thoracoabdominal nerves (T7–T11), subcostal (T12), and contributions from iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves (L1), coordinating trunk flexion and abdominal compression.Clinical Application: Knowledge of this innervation helps when working with patients recovering from abdominal surgery or sports injuries.Which nerves innervate the external oblique muscle?Your answer: No answerCorrect answer: Thoracoabdominal nerves (T7–T11) and subcostal nerve (T12)Explanation: The external oblique is innervated by lower thoracic spinal nerves.More Info: Thoracoabdominal nerves (continuations of intercostals) from T7–T11 and the subcostal nerve (T12) supply the external oblique. These nerves allow trunk motion and abdominal wall compression.Clinical Application: A massage therapist targeting abdominal breathing or tension may stimulate these nerves for relaxation.Answered: 1 / 2(Some questions were skipped or left unanswered)Close

Transverse abdominis" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_010-3-0-cc499a29-2445-49c9-8b2d-c64dcf18ba44" aria-label="Option D: Transverse abdominis" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_010-0-cc499a29-2445-49c9-8b2d-c64dcf18ba44" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_010-3-0-cc499a29-2445-49c9-8b2d-c64dcf18ba44" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">D.</label> Transverse abdominis</div></li></ul></fieldset><div class="quiz-explanation">Quick Tip: All these muscles contract to assist in expelling air from the lungs.</div><div style="color: rgb(37, 99, 235); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 15px;">More Info: During forced expiration, abdominal muscles contract to compress the abdominal cavity, elevate the diaphragm, and push air out. This includes the rectus, obliques, and transverse muscles.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: Massage can facilitate more effective breathing by improving abdominal compliance and reducing tension in these muscles.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;">Source: Clinical Anatomy – Snell</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;"><span>Tags: expiration, abdominals, forced breathing </span><span>Keywords: respiratory function, abdominal compression, core</span></div><div class="quiz-actions" role="group" aria-label="Quiz navigation actions"><button disabled="" aria-label="Previous question" role="button" aria-disabled="true">Previous</button><button disabled="" aria-label="Next question" role="button" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="0" data-testid="quiz-next-btn" style="visibility: visible;">Next</button><button aria-label="Finish quiz early" role="button" disabled="" aria-disabled="true">Finish</button></div></div></main></main><footer class="app-footer"><input class="question-search-bar" placeholder="Search questions..." aria-label="Search questions" type="text"></footer></div>

It’s key in abdominal wall stability and core strength.Clinical Application: Massage that encourages deep abdominal relaxation can improve coordination of the transverse abdominis for core support.Where does the internal oblique muscle originate?Your answer: No answerCorrect answer: Thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, and inguinal ligamentExplanation: The internal oblique arises from fascia and bony landmarks of the lower torso.More Info: This muscle originates from the thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, and lateral half of the inguinal ligament. It contributes to trunk rotation and compression of abdominal contents.Clinical Application: In cases of lateral strain or scoliosis, internal oblique involvement may be targeted in therapy.Answered: 1 / 2(Some questions were skipped or left unanswered)Close

Xiphoid process" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_001-1-0-81a08de6-352a-4e71-aab5-3fc07e7fa3cc" aria-label="Option B: Xiphoid process" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_001-0-81a08de6-352a-4e71-aab5-3fc07e7fa3cc" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_001-1-0-81a08de6-352a-4e71-aab5-3fc07e7fa3cc" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">B.</label> Xiphoid process</div></li><li><div class="quiz-option" data-testid="quiz-option" data-qa="quiz-option" role="group" aria-label="Quiz option: C. Iliac crest" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_001-2-0-81a08de6-352a-4e71-aab5-3fc07e7fa3cc" aria-label="Option C: Iliac crest" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_001-0-81a08de6-352a-4e71-aab5-3fc07e7fa3cc" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_001-2-0-81a08de6-352a-4e71-aab5-3fc07e7fa3cc" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">C.</label> Iliac crest</div></li><li><div class="quiz-option" data-testid="quiz-option" data-qa="quiz-option" role="group" aria-label="Quiz option: D. Costal cartilages of ribs 5-7" style="width: 100%; cursor: pointer;"><input id="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_001-3-0-81a08de6-352a-4e71-aab5-3fc07e7fa3cc" aria-label="Option D: Costal cartilages of ribs 5-7" aria-checked="false" aria-disabled="false" role="radio" data-disabled="false" tabindex="-1" data-quiz-radio="true" data-testid="quiz-radio" type="radio" name="quiz-question-abdominal_muscle_origins_001-0-81a08de6-352a-4e71-aab5-3fc07e7fa3cc" style="margin-right: 12px; cursor: pointer;"><label for="quiz-option-abdominal_muscle_origins_001-3-0-81a08de6-352a-4e71-aab5-3fc07e7fa3cc" style="font-weight: 600; margin-right: 8px; cursor: pointer;">D.</label> Costal cartilages of ribs 5-7</div></li></ul></fieldset><div class="quiz-explanation">Quick Tip: The rectus abdominis originates from the pubic crest and symphysis.</div><div style="color: rgb(37, 99, 235); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 15px;">More Info: The rectus abdominis muscle originates from the pubic crest and pubic symphysis and inserts on the xiphoid process and costal cartilages of ribs 5–7. It plays a vital role in trunk flexion and intra-abdominal pressure regulation.</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 14px;">Clinical Application: Understanding this helps massage therapists treat lower abdominal strain or address postural imbalance in anterior pelvic tilt.</div><div style="color: rgb(161, 98, 7); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;">Source: Trail Guide to the Body – Biel</div><div style="color: rgb(100, 116, 139); margin-top: 8px; font-size: 13px;"><span>Tags: rectus abdominis, origin, core muscles </span><span>Keywords: pubic crest, abdominal muscle, origin</span></div><div class="quiz-actions" role="group" aria-label="Quiz navigation actions"><button disabled="" aria-label="Previous question" role="button" aria-disabled="true">Previous</button><button disabled="" aria-label="Next question" role="button" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="0" data-testid="quiz-next-btn" style="visibility: visible;">Next</button><button aria-label="Finish quiz early" role="button" disabled="" aria-disabled="true">Finish</button></div></div></main></main><footer class="app-footer"><input class="question-search-bar" placeholder="Search questions..." aria-label="Search questions" type="text"></footer></div>

It plays a vital role in trunk flexion and intra-abdominal pressure regulation.Clinical Application: Understanding this helps massage therapists treat lower abdominal strain or address postural imbalance in anterior pelvic tilt.Answered: 1 / 1Close

These nerves allow trunk motion and abdominal wall compression.Clinical Application: A massage therapist targeting abdominal breathing or tension may stimulate these nerves for relaxation.Answered: 1 / 2(Some questions were skipped or left unanswered)Close
